Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: Distributed Computing Laboratory for Large Scale System Modeling and Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to acquire an 8 node multicore hybrid CPU+GPU system in support of research in use of multicore-based, GPU-based and hybrid high performance computing applications in the areas of large and complex system modeling and their solution methods, computational fluid dynamics, high performance data and stream processing, and dependable and high integrity methods on hybrid multicore and GPU methods. The proposed configuration also includes one front node and one storage server node with 80 TB disk capacity interconnected by an existing Infiniband network for multi-tiered, hierarchical parallel computing. Each compute node consists of Quad AMD new Interlagos processor 6220 with 8-core operating at 3.0GHz (can go up to 3.6GHz) and 512 GB of RAM, and a dual 448-core Tesla Fermi GPUs with 6 GB memory. The system will be used to support CISE centric interdisciplinary high performance computing research.
This project establishes a computational instrument deploying multiple multicore hybrid CPU+GPU systems to support applications requiring hybrid high performance computing machinery. The instrumentation facilitates research in multicore- and GPU-based high performance computing in the context of the diverse set of applications at the frontiers of research: modeling of large and complex systems and their solution methods, such as high performance data and stream processing, dependable and high integrity methods on hybrid multicore and GPU, and computational fluid dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to build a machine by connecting multicore CPUs and GPUs (graphics processing units) to support ISU researchers in developing applications in large scale system modeling and analysis, developing solutions for sustainable and risk-resilient energy and other infrastructures’ planning and operation problems, solving large scale unstructured grid analysis using GPUs, processing large data sets and streams, and planning fault tolerance communication structure to support large-scale computing.

 

A few specific outcomes, where research was facilitated by this machine, are described below.

 

Maximal Clique Enumeration. With the emergence of social networks, data mining on web data provides useful information to understand relationship among the various entities. A similar need exists in biological and other networks to discover interactions and their impacts. The entities in such networks are their interactions are represented using a graph structure and a maximal clique algorithm identifies most dense substructure in such a connected graph.

The researchers at Iowa State University (ISU) have developed a new algorithm Parallel Enumeration of Cliques using Ordering (PECO) that identifies such connections in one step that does not require any post processing to remove duplicate and non-maximal cliques. PECO outperforms all currently known parallel (and sequential) methods for the problem.

 

Tree Matching Using Data Shaping: Real time big data analytics to make business and other decision making needs in many complex applications is based on use of semi-structured data stored in tree-based organizations. ISU researchers the problem of shaping the semi-structured data to enable time efficient processing on contemporary hardware such as GPGPU and Intel MIC. We have developed novel data shaping technique which enables pre-computation of partial edit distance values in parallel. Our PTED-GPU (Parallel Tree Edit Distance using GPU) algorithm speedups the application by a factor of 10 when compared to the state-of-the-art in tree edit distance (TED) computation.

 

Quorum theory in unique and non-traditional ways to Communications. It is common for a group to communicate on one-on-one or one-to-many manner. For efficiency and efficient control, it is common in distributed systems and algorithms to group nodes into intersecting sets referred to as quorum sets. Quorum-based cycle routing can efficiently support arbitrary point-to-point and multi-point optical communications. Cycles are created using quorums of nodes. Within a cycle, multicasts to all nodes in that cycle are possible. Specific cyclic quorums set possess “all-pairs” property that guarantees unicast capabilities in a network using the quorum cycles routing technique. Fault tolerance in such communications refers to developing quorum-based cycles where each pair of nodes is connected in more than one (R in case of R-redundancy) cycles. Searching for such specific cycles is intense in computation. We developed methods to search for such cycles and shown that it is possible to design communication structure using this method. We analyzed the current strengths and opportunities for improvements to R redundant quorum-based single cycle routing.

 

Role of the unique plumage of the owl in its silent flight, with the objective of designing bio-inspired, ultra-quiet propulsion systems for next-gen aircraft and wind turbines. Wind is a renewal source of energy. Designing efficient wind tower and blades is an important part of the research in this area. The goal of this research is to (i) use high-fidelity tools to understand sound/noise generation due to flow over an owl wing, and (ii) adapt the owl plumage to design quiet blades. Researchers verified their aeroacoustics models against experimental data for a model problem and evaluated a leading edge serration design (inspired by serrations found on owl wings) leads to noise reduction using passive methods. This will lead to designing quiet rotor blades for next-gen aircraft and wind turbines.

Power system time domain simulations or dynamic security assessment (DSA). Maintaining the security and reliability of power systems is absolutely essential to keep our country safe. Dynamic security assessment using time-domain methods is an effective means. However, these computations are intense and through parallelization of the contingency analysis for dynamic security is achieved by partitioning the network into a number of appropriate subnetworks. We verified the analysis accuracy of such systems using small test system and scaled the analysis to large systems.

Parallelization of Data De-duplication for Document Databases. In bigdata era, semi-structured forms of data and document-oriented databases are gaining prominence. To ensure high availability, the document databases deploy replication. That leads to another interesting issue of data de-duplication removal. The goal is to identify fingerprint of files that will help in duplicate searches using accelerators such as GPGPUs. We developed structure-aware data shaping method to reduce the computational complexity of duplicate chunk to facilitate efficient usage of GPGPU. Experiments with real datasets demonstrate that our GPGPU-based solution achieves a throughput of more than 1 million chunks per seconds.

 

The projected created large broader scientific impact in multiple areas including education and workforce development.
